patient_information: Age: 42 years Sex: male Residence: Malawi Occupation: British expatriate
chief_complaint: Anaphylactic shock with rash, difficulty in breathing, and feeling of impending death.
history_of_present_illness: A 42-year-old British male expatriate who has lived in Malawi for 18 months presents to the local hospital emergency room with a florid itchy rash, difficulty in breathing, and a feeling he is going to die. He relates this to a tick bite on his ankle 2 days prior while out walking in the countryside.
exposure_and_epidemiology: Travel history: Recent travel to rural Malawi one week prior Vector exposures: Mosquito exposure implied by endemic setting Animal exposures: No animal or water/food exposures reported Contact exposures: No sick contacts reported
vitals: Temperature: 38Â°C Pulse rate: 130 bpm Systolic blood pressure: 60 mmHg Respiratory rate: not reported Oxygen saturation: not reported
physical_exam: General appearance: Clammy, in a state of collapse Rash description: Widespread urticarial rash Respiratory system: Respiratory distress and stridor Ankle swelling: Indurated circumscribed swelling on the inside of his left ankle
labs_and_diagnostics: Hemoglobin: 17.4 d/dL White cell count: 6.1 G/L (polymorphs 85%, lymphocytes 10%) Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 5 mm/hour Blood film for malaria parasites: Negative Chest radiograph: Normal Stool and urine microscopy: Negative
differential_diagnosis: Trypanosomiasis: Considered due to circumscribed swelling on the ankle, positive family history of allergy, and possible tick bite. Malaria: Less likely given dengue confirmation and no malaria-specific findings reported. Chikungunya: Not considered as dengue was confirmed.
management_and_clinical_course: Initial treatment: Supportive care with oral/IV fluids, acetaminophen, and adrenaline Suramin treatment: Given a test dose of suramin 0.25g with no ill effect, followed by weekly doses totaling 5.75g without complications. Clinical improvement: Improvement noted after treatment; rash resolved, stridor ceased, and patient became less breathless.
final_diagnosis: Diagnosis: Trypanosomiasis due to Trypanosoma brucei rhodesiense Confirmation method: Positive family history of allergy, circumscribed swelling on the ankle, and trypanosomes identified in thick blood film. Alternative exclusions: Malaria ruled out by negative blood film for parasites.
